conversation.content: [slurring] Hey, can you settle something for me? My friend says octopuses have three hearts.
Your friend's absolutely right. They have one main heart for the body and two smaller ones just for pumping blood through their gills. Pretty efficient system actually.
No way. Three hearts? Why would anything need three hearts?
It's all about oxygen distribution. Their blood uses copper instead of iron, which makes it less efficient at carrying oxygen. The extra hearts compensate for that.
Copper blood? Now you're just making stuff up.
Completely serious. That's why their blood is blue instead of red. The copper-based hemocyanin works better in cold, low-oxygen environments like the deep ocean.
Okay, what else is weird about them?
They have no bones at all. Can squeeze through any opening bigger than their beak. Plus each arm basically has its own brain—they're practically nine brains working together.
Nine brains?!
[shouting] Yes! One central brain and a mini-brain in each arm! Two-thirds of their neurons are in their arms, not their head!
That's insane. How do they coordinate anything?
[laugh histerically] That's the thing—they kind of don't! Each arm can act independently while the main brain handles the big-picture stuff. It's controlled chaos.
Do they feel pain?
[regretful] They do, unfortunately. Studies show they avoid locations where they've been hurt before. Some countries now require anesthesia if you're doing research on them.
Wait, how do you anesthetize an octopus?
Usually magnesium chloride in their water. Knocks them right out. Though ethanol works too—essentially getting them drunk before procedures.
[belly laugh] You're telling me scientists get octopuses drunk?
[shy] Well, when you put it that way it sounds ridiculous. But it's a legitimate anesthetic protocol. Very carefully measured doses, obviously.
What's the smartest thing you've seen one do?
There's video of one carrying coconut shells across the ocean floor to use as portable shelter later. That's tool use and planning ahead—seriously advanced cognition for an invertebrate.
